The '''COVID-19 pandemic in Macau''' is part of the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic|worldwide pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] ({{nowrap|COVID-19}}) caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] ({{nowrap|SARS-CoV-2}}). The first case of the disease in [[Macau]] was confirmed on 22 January 2020. The city saw nine more cases by 4 February, but no more cases until 15 March, when imported cases began to appear.<ref name="US News 24 Mar">{{cite news|last1=Keegan |first1=Matthew |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/cities/articles/2020-03-24/macau-how-a-densely-populated-chinese-territory-is-keeping-coronavirus-at-bay |title=Lessons From Macau, the Densely Populated Region Beating Back COVID-19 |work=[[U.S. News and World Report]] |date=2020-03-24 |accessdate=2020-04-10}}</ref> {{As of|2020|7|17}}, the city has 46 cumulative confirmed cases of COVID-19, all of those having recovered, and no deaths from the disease.<ref name="SSM special" /> Stringent government measures have included the 15-day closure of all 81 [[Gambling in Macau|casinos in the territory]] in February; in addition, effective 25 March, the territory disallowed connecting flights at [[Macau International Airport|its airport]] as well as entry by all non-residents (excepting residents of mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan), and from 6 April, the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]] was closed to public transport and most other traffic.

The '''COVID-19 pandemic in Macau''' is part of the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic|worldwide pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] ({{nowrap|COVID-19}}) caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] ({{nowrap|SARS-CoV-2}}). The first case of the disease in [[Macau]] was confirmed on 22 January 2020. The city saw nine more cases by 4 February, but no more cases until 15 March, when imported cases began to appear.<ref name="US News 24 Mar">{{cite news|last1=Keegan |first1=Matthew |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/cities/articles/2020-03-24/macau-how-a-densely-populated-chinese-territory-is-keeping-coronavirus-at-bay |title=Lessons From Macau, the Densely Populated Region Beating Back COVID-19 |work=[[U.S. News and World Report]] |date=2020-03-24 |accessdate=2020-04-10}}</ref> {{As of|2020|7|17}}, the city has 46 cumulative confirmed cases of COVID-19, all of those having recovered, and no deaths from the disease.<ref name="SSM special" />
  +   +
Stringent government measures have included the 15-day closure of all 81 [[Gambling in Macau|casinos in the territory]] in February; in addition, effective 25 March, the territory disallowed connecting flights at [[Macau International Airport|its airport]] as well as entry by all non-residents (excepting residents of mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan), and from 6 April, the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]] was closed to public transport and most other traffic.

revisions.*: {{short description|Ongoing COVID-19 viral pandemic in Macau}} {{EngvarB|date=February 2020}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2020}}{{Infobox pandemic | name = COVID-19 pandemic in Macau | map1 = COVID-19 Outbreak Cases in Macau.svg | legend1 = {{center|Map of parishes with confirmed (red) coronavirus cases (as of 29 March)}} | map2 = | legend2 = | map3 = | legend3 = | disease = [[COVID-19]] | virus_strain = [[SARS-CoV-2]] | location = [[Macau]] | first_case = | date = 22 January 2020 – 17 July 2020 | origin = [[Wuhan]], [[Hubei]], China | confirmed_cases = 46{{cite web|url=https://www.ssm.gov.mo/apps1/PreventCOVID-19/en.aspx |title=Macao Government Special webpage against Epidemics |publisher=Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, Macau |accessdate=2020-04-10}} | suspected_cases = | recovery_cases = 46 | deaths = 0 | total_ili = | website = [https://www.ssm.gov.mo/apps1/PreventWuhanInfection/en.aspx Macao Government Special webpage against Epidemics] }} The '''COVID-19 pandemic in Macau''' is part of the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic|worldwide pandemic]] of [[coronavirus disease 2019]] ({{nowrap|COVID-19}}) caused by [[severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2]] ({{nowrap|SARS-CoV-2}}). The first case of the disease in [[Macau]] was confirmed on 22 January 2020. The city saw nine more cases by 4 February, but no more cases until 15 March, when imported cases began to appear.{{cite news|last1=Keegan |first1=Matthew |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/cities/articles/2020-03-24/macau-how-a-densely-populated-chinese-territory-is-keeping-coronavirus-at-bay |title=Lessons From Macau, the Densely Populated Region Beating Back COVID-19 |work=[[U.S. News and World Report]] |date=2020-03-24 |accessdate=2020-04-10}} {{As of|2020|7|17}}, the city has 46 cumulative confirmed cases of COVID-19, all of those having recovered, and no deaths from the disease. Stringent government measures have included the 15-day closure of all 81 [[Gambling in Macau|casinos in the territory]] in February; in addition, effective 25 March, the territory disallowed connecting flights at [[Macau International Airport|its airport]] as well as entry by all non-residents (excepting residents of mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan), and from 6 April, the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]] was closed to public transport and most other traffic. ==Timeline== {{COVID-19 pandemic data/Macau medical cases chart}} ===First wave=== On 22 January 2020, Macau confirmed two COVID-19 cases, that of a 52-year-old woman and of a 66-year-old man, both from [[Wuhan]].{{Cite news |url=https://hk.on.cc/hk/bkn/cnt/news/20200123/mobile/bkn-20200123095348297-0123_00822_001.html |date=23 January 2020 |work=on.cc |access-date=23 January 2020 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200124014056/https://hk.on.cc/hk/bkn/cnt/news/20200123/mobile/bkn-20200123095348297-0123_00822_001.html |archive-date=24 January 2020 |language=zh-hk |script-title=zh:澳門確診第2宗武漢肺炎 患者為66歲男遊客}} On the morning of 26 January, the Macau Health Bureau confirmed three additional cases: that of a 58-year-old woman arriving from [[Hong Kong]] on 23 January after travelling to Wuhan, and of two women, aged 21 and 39, both arriving in Macau on 22 January via the [[Lotus Bridge]]; all three were residents of Wuhan. The Macau government has since temporarily closed all schools and universities, and has imposed border controls with temperature checks.{{cite web|url=https://macaunews.mo/government-confirms-5-cases-of-coronavirus-so-far-in-macau/|title=Government confirms 5 cases of coronavirus so far in Macau|date=26 January 2020|website=Macau News|access-date=2020-01-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200126102217/https://macaunews.mo/government-confirms-5-cases-of-coronavirus-so-far-in-macau/|archive-date=26 January 2020|url-status=live}} The government also declared the closing of several venues to limit the possible spread of the virus, including several entertainment venues and planned Lunar New Year performances.{{cite web|url=https://www.asgam.com/index.php/2020/01/28/macau-irs-close-facilities-as-confirmed-coronavirus-cases-reach-seven/|title=Macau IRs close facilities as confirmed Coronavirus cases reach seven|last=|first=|date=28 January 2020|website=Inside Asian Gaming|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129140552/https://www.asgam.com/index.php/2020/01/28/macau-irs-close-facilities-as-confirmed-coronavirus-cases-reach-seven/|archive-date=29 January 2020|accessdate=30 January 2020}} On 27 January, a 15-year-old boy, the son of one of the previously confirmed patients, was declared the sixth case of the virus in Macau.{{cite web|url=https://macaunews.mo/15-year-old-wuhan-boy-confirmed-as-the-sixth-coronavirus-case-in-macau/|title=15-year-old Wuhan boy confirmed as the sixth coronavirus case in Macau|last=|first=|date=27 January 2020|website=Macau News|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129141126/https://macaunews.mo/15-year-old-wuhan-boy-confirmed-as-the-sixth-coronavirus-case-in-macau/|archive-date=29 January 2020|access-date=30 January 2020}} The next day, the seventh case was announced, that of a 67-year-old woman, a resident of Wuhan who travelled to [[Guangzhou]] before entering Macau through the Barrier Gate checkpoint.{{cite web|url=https://macaunews.mo/macau-confirms-7th-wuhan-virus-case-in-a-deserted-city/|title=Macau confirms 7th Wuhan virus case in a deserted city|last=|first=|date=28 January 2020|website=Macau News|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129150822/https://macaunews.mo/macau-confirms-7th-wuhan-virus-case-in-a-deserted-city/|archive-date=29 January 2020|access-date=30 January 2020}} On 6 March, all 10 confirmed patients with the virus had recovered. According to authorities, however, there are still 224 people in isolation, 6 in quarantine, and 58 Macau residents who have been to South Korea and Italy also isolated.{{cite news |url=https://macaunews.mo/no-more-covid-19-cases-in-macau/ |title=No more COVID-19 cases in Macau |work=Macau News |date=6 March 2020 |accessdate=7 March 2020}} On 7 March, the Philippines announced that an airlift operation will be launched to bring home 167 Filipinos working in Macau.{{Cite news |last=Modesto |first=Catherine A. |url=https://www.cnnphilippines.com/news/2020/3/7/macau-evacuees-go-home-march-7.html |title=163 stranded Filipinos from Macau arrive home |date=2020-03-07 |work=CNN Philippines}} ===Second wave=== On 15 March, the city registered a new COVID-19 case imported from Portugal, the first new case in over a month. The patient is a Korean migrant worker who visited her boyfriend's family in the city of [[Porto]]. The woman departed Macau on January 30. She flew back to Hong Kong from Dubai on March 13 on flight number EK380, taking seat 31J. She returned to Macau on the same day via the [[Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge]]. Later in the day she started experiencing coughing and went to the hospital on Sunday afternoon, March 15, with fever.{{cite web|url=https://macaunews.mo/macau-recorded-the-11th-case-of-covid-19/ |title=Macau records its 11th case of COVID-19 | Macau News |publisher=Macaunews.mo |date=2020-03-16 |accessdate=2020-03-31}} On 17 March, two new cases were reported. The first patient, a 47-year-old male, is a Spanish national doing business in Macau; he took the SU2501 flight from Madrid to Moscow on March 15, and then the SU204 flight from Moscow to Beijing. On 16 March, he took the NX001 flight from Beijing to Macau, arriving at Macau Airport at 8:00 pm of the same day. The second patient is a 20-year-old woman, a Macau resident who was studying in the United Kingdom. The patient left London and arrived at the [[Hong Kong International Airport]] via Kuala Lumpur on the night of March 16. Upon arrival at the [[Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge]], she was detected to have a fever and was immediately taken to the hospital. Further testing revealed she was infected with the novel coronavirus.{{cite web|url=https://www.tdm.com.mo/c_news/radio_news.php?id=460383 |title=電台新聞>本澳今日確診2宗新冠肺炎(2020.03.17 19:47) |publisher=Tdm.com.mo |date=2020-03-17 |accessdate=2020-03-31}} On 19 March, the [[Education and Youth Affairs Bureau (Macau)|Education and Youth Affairs Bureau]] announced the re-postponement of its plans to resume primary and secondary education as a response to the second wave of COVID-19 cases beginning with the 11th case.{{Cite web |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20CS1PR97 |title=Class resumption for non-tertiary education schools will be postponed until further notice |last=Education and Youth Affairs Bureau |date=2020-03-19 |website=news.gov.mo |publisher=Government Information Bureau}} This is after the bureau's class resumption plans starting on 30 March, announced on 11 March.{{Cite web |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20CJOAuRT |title=DSEJ formulates a plan for class resumption of non-tertiary education schools |last=Education and Youth Affairs Bureau |date=2020-03-11 |website=news.gov.mo |publisher=Government Information Bureau}} On 27 March, the government of neighbouring [[Zhuhai]] announced that anyone returning or travelling from outside Mainland China (including Macau and Hong Kong) would undergo mandatory 14-day quarantine with a few exceptions.{{Cite web |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20CaKhyeq |last=Government Information Bureau |date=2020-03-27 |website=news.gov.mo |publisher=Government Information Bureau |language=zh |script-title=zh:【圖文包】出入境豁免情況和出入境特別手續}} This caused large crowds and chaos at the [[Lótus Bridge|Lotus Checkpoint]] in [[Cotai]], which was the only border checkpoint open at the time.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}} On 19 June, 300 Filipinos who were living in Macau were airlifted in an operation headed by the Philippine Consulate General in Macau.{{Cite web|url=https://macaunews.mo/over-300-filipinos-returned-home-on-thursday/|title=Over 300 Filipinos returned home on Thursday|date=18 June 2020}} ==Response and impact== ===December 2019=== On 31 December 2019, the [[Health Bureau]] was notified by the [[National Health Commission]] of an outbreak of pneumonia of unknown cause in [[Wuhan]]. Residents were asked to avoid excessive panic but to be conscious of personal hygiene and the hygiene of their environment. Those travelling to Wuhan were advised to avoid visiting local hospitals or having contact with sick people.{{cite web |script-title=zh:衛生局接國家衛健委通報武漢不明原因肺炎 已有機制監測及應對市民毋須過分恐慌 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/312595/ |publisher=SSM (Macao Health Bureau) |language=zh-tw |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207071843/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AAECxlQ;jsessionid=9665DE00A598BF844DDF6A08E7161D73.app02?0 |archivedate=2019-12-31 |url-status=live}} ===January 2020=== On 1 January 2020, the Macao Health Bureau asked [[Macau International Airport]] to implement body temperature screening for all passengers on flights coming from Wuhan.{{Cite web |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AAECxlQ |last=Health Bureau |date=2020-01-01 |website=news.gov.mo |publisher=Government Information Bureau |language=zh-tw |script-title=zh:今天起對來自武漢航班乘客進行體温篩查 衛生局與國家衛生健康委員保持密切聯繫 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207071843/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AAECxlQ;jsessionid=9665DE00A598BF844DDF6A08E7161D73.app02?0 |archive-date=2020-02-07 |access-date=2020-01-02}} Starting 5 January, the Health Bureau raised the pneumonia warning level to 3, medium risk, and on the same day established the "Interdepartmental Working Group Against Pneumonia of Unknown Cause" (應對不明原因肺炎跨部門工作小組).{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AEUUwwZ |script-title=zh:特區政府提昇對"武漢不明原因肺炎"的預警級別至第III級(較重) 衛生局呼籲市民提高防範意識 |date=2020-01-05 |publisher=SSM (Macao Health Bureau) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207072051/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AEUUwwZ;jsessionid=2C12CEB2F0CA4908E13CF5B20217344E.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |access-date=2020-01-11}} Starting 10 January, people bought large quantities of masks, leading to shortages in some pharmacies. ''[[Macao Daily News]]'' reported that, according to the Health Bureau, the city's supply of masks was sufficient.{{Cite news |url=http://www.macaodaily.com/html/2020-01/10/content_1408320.htm |script-title=zh:口罩充足毋恐慌 應對肺炎及早防 |date=2020-01-10 |newspaper=澳门日报 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207072757/http://www.macaodaily.com/html/2020-01/10/content_1408320.htm |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |language=zh}} On the day that the first case in Macau was confirmed, the Health Bureau announced at a press conference the imposition of rationing starting in the evening of 23 January: Macau residents and foreign workers could use [[Macau Resident Identity Card]]s and foreign worker identity cards respectively to purchase up to 10 masks per person every 10 days. Director of the Health Bureau Lei Chin Ion (李展潤) said that out of 294 pharmacies in Macau, 160 did not have masks and that out of eight mask suppliers, one had 150,000 masks remaining in stock whereas the others were out of stock.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AVJspef |script-title=zh:衛生局將推出保障口罩供應澳門居民計劃 確保居民可購買到所需口罩 |date=2020-01-22 |newspaper=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207073025/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AVJspef;jsessionid=4EE7B5BEBF6A13FA624B6707AA84E3F1.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |language=zh}} On 21 January, [[Chief Executive of Macau|Chief Executive]] [[Ho Iat Seng]] ordered the establishment of a 24-hour "Novel Coronavirus Emergency Coordination Center", replacing the "Interdepartmental Working Group Against Pneumonia of Unknown Cause", to operate directly under the chief executive, with Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture as vice chair.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AUAWxeo |script-title=zh:特區政府提昇對"武漢不明原因肺炎"的預警級別至第III級(較重) 衛生局呼籲市民提高防範意識 |date=2020-01-21 |publisher=SSM (Macao Health Bureau) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207072247/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AUAWxeo;jsessionid=90528C1EE65EC09E19A413B749F04296.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |access-date=2020-01-11}}{{cite web |script-title=zh:印務局 - 行政長官批示 |url=https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/03/despce_cn.asp |accessdate=2020-02-01 |work=bo.io.gov.mo |publisher=印務局 |language=zh-Hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200201091940/https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/03/despce_cn.asp |archivedate=2020-02-01 |url-status=live}} In response to the city's first imported case, steps were taken, including: border control points implemented health declarations,{{cite web |script-title=zh:【武漢肺炎】澳門所有口岸實施健康申報 乘金巴入境須填表 |url=https://std.stheadline.com/instant/articles/detail/1186708/ |accessdate=2020-01-23 |date=2020-01-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207072444/https://std.stheadline.com/instant/articles/detail/1186708/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E9%A6%99%E6%B8%AF-%E6%AD%A6%E6%BC%A2%E8%82%BA%E7%82%8E-%E6%BE%B3%E9%96%80%E6%89%80%E6%9C%89%E5%8F%A3%E5%B2%B8%E5%AF%A6%E6%96%BD%E5%81%A5%E5%BA%B7%E7%94%B3%E5%A0%B1-%E4%B9%98%E9%87%91%E5%B7%B4%E5%85%A5%E5%A2%83%E9%A0%88%E5%A1%AB%E8%A1%A8 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |website=星島日報}} resort workers had to wear masks, Macau residents were not encouraged to travel to Wuhan, and tour groups between Wuhan and Macau were suspended.{{cite web |script-title=zh:政府全力應對加強防控疫情 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/314827/ |accessdate=2020-01-23 |date=2020-01-22 |language=zh-hant |url-status=live |author1=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心 |website=澳門特別行政區政府入口網站 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200124152435/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/314827/ |archive-date=2020-01-24}}{{cite web|script-title=zh:澳門11日無確診 何栢良：控疫勝港 稱找出湖北客關鍵 早切斷隱形傳播鏈|url=https://m.mingpao.com/pns/%E8%A6%81%E8%81%9E/article/20200216/s00001/1581789946951/%E6%BE%B3%E9%96%8011%E6%97%A5%E7%84%A1%E7%A2%BA%E8%A8%BA-%E4%BD%95%E6%A0%A2%E8%89%AF-%E6%8E%A7%E7%96%AB%E5%8B%9D%E6%B8%AF-%E7%A8%B1%E6%89%BE%E5%87%BA%E6%B9%96%E5%8C%97%E5%AE%A2%E9%97%9C%E9%8D%B5-%E6%97%A9%E5%88%87%E6%96%B7%E9%9A%B1%E5%BD%A2%E5%82%B3%E6%92%AD%E9%8F%88|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200217151832/https://m.mingpao.com/pns/%E8%A6%81%E8%81%9E/article/20200216/s00001/1581789946951/%E6%BE%B3%E9%96%8011%E6%97%A5%E7%84%A1%E7%A2%BA%E8%A8%BA-%E4%BD%95%E6%A0%A2%E8%89%AF-%E6%8E%A7%E7%96%AB%E5%8B%9D%E6%B8%AF-%E7%A8%B1%E6%89%BE%E5%87%BA%E6%B9%96%E5%8C%97%E5%AE%A2%E9%97%9C%E9%8D%B5-%E6%97%A9%E5%88%87%E6%96%B7%E9%9A%B1%E5%BD%A2%E5%82%B3%E6%92%AD%E9%8F%88|archivedate=2020-02-17|accessdate=2020-02-17|date=2020-02-17|work=明報}} On 23 January, Macau confirmed its second imported case, leading the Government Tourism Office to cancel all Chinese New Year celebrations, including the Macau Chinese New Year Parade.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AW8tgPg |script-title=zh:政府取消新春大型公眾活動 降低傳染病傳播風險 |date=2020-01-23 |publisher=澳門新聞局 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207073332/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AW8tgPg;jsessionid=66F89CB747B12058FF7648786127368F.app02?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} On the same day, Ho Iat Seng announced that anyone with fever symptoms should not leave Macau. On January 23, Ho Iat Seng announced that Macau had ordered 20 million masks to sell to Macau residents and foreign workers at cost.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AWOxBz2 |script-title=zh:行政長官：加強防控 安度春節 |date=2020-01-23 |publisher=澳門新聞局 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207073530/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AWOxBz2;jsessionid=DAA9C5B9204BB1D2539118C50E12066B.app03?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} The Correctional Services Authority announced precautions against the virus.{{cite web|script-title=zh:懲教管理局實施預防新型冠狀病毒的措施|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/314975/|accessdate=2020-03-28|author=懲教管理局|date=2020-01-23|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200328051859/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/314975/|archivedate=2020-03-28|url-status=live}} On 24 January, the [[Education and Youth Affairs Bureau (Macau)|Education and Youth Affairs Bureau]] announced that all non-tertiary schools would extend their Chinese New Year holiday, not resuming classes until February 10 or later. The bureau also asked other private tutoring and continuing education centers to delay the resumption of classes.{{Cite news |url=https://hk.news.appledaily.com/local/20200124/K3HGL5C4TWLPPTKT6JEXUYQM5M/ |script-title=zh:【武漢肺炎】澳門宣佈中小學新年假後延期上課 籲校安排學生留家學習 |date=2020-01-24 |work=蘋果日報 |url-status=live}} On the same day, the Tertiary Education Bureau also announced that ten tertiary institutions would delay classes until February 11.{{cite web|script-title=zh:澳門十高校延後至2月11日開學-高等教育局|url=https://www.dses.gov.mo/news/5162-2020-01-24|accessdate=2020-01-26|website=dses.gov.mo|date=2020-01-24|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200126024001/https://www.dses.gov.mo/news/5162-2020-01-24|archive-date=2020-01-26}} The Sports Bureau later announced that sporting facilities would be closed from that afternoon (24 January) at 4PM.{{cite web|script-title=zh:體育局轄下體育設施今午四時起暫停開放|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/315058/|accessdate=2020-03-10|author=體育局|date=2020-01-24|format=|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200310135821/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/315058/|archivedate=2020-03-10|url-status=live}} On 25 January, the government of Macau announced that the opening hours at the [[Posto Fronteiriço das Portas do Cerco|Portas do Cerco border crossing]] with [[Zhuhai]] would be reduced by three hours, to 6AM–10PM, until further notice. Opening hours at other border crossings with Zhuhai and Hong Kong would not be affected for the time being.{{Cite news |url=https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/ch/component/k2/1504833-20200125.htm?archive_date=2020-01-25 |script-title=zh:澳門宣布關閘拱北口岸人車通關時間縮短3小時 |date=2020-01-25 |work=香港電台 |url-status=live |access-date=2020-01-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200125145402/https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/ch/component/k2/1504833-20200125.htm%3Farchive_date%3D2020-01-25 |archive-date=2020-01-25 |language=zh}} On the same day, the Macau government announced that they would donate 50,000 urgently needed medical masks to the city of Zhuhai, to be used for the prevention and treatment of the virus.{{cite news |script-title=zh:拱北海关快速验放澳门捐赠珠海5万个医用口罩 |url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-01/25/c_1125501932.htm |url-status=live |agency=新华网 |access-date=2020-01-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200126113849/http://www.xinhuanet.com/2020-01/25/c_1125501932.htm |archive-date=2020-01-26}} On 26 January, the government announced that starting on the 27th, all non-residents who were from or had been to Hubei in the past 14 days were required to have a doctor's note certifying that they did not have the virus in order to be allowed into Macau. In addition, anyone who had been to Hubei in the past 14 days was prohibited from entering casinos.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AaeveUQ |script-title=zh:限制入境澳門前14日內曾到湖北省人士進入娛樂場 |date=2020-01-27 |publisher=博彩監察協調局 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207073832/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AaeveUQ;jsessionid=6586AFC3DEF51B5F887875E59B51BAC7.app02?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} That evening the government of Macau announced that starting at 9AM on the 27th, the 1,113 travellers from Hubei who had entered Macau between 1 December and 26 January and remained in the territory would be quarantined.{{Cite news |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20Aa8HHeL |script-title=zh:治安警積極配合特區政府防疫工作 |date=2020-01-27 |publisher=治安警察局 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207074009/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20Aa8HHeL;jsessionid=ACBA16C393CFB50B3763BD3BD8A14BAD.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} On 28 January, [[Secretariat for Administration and Justice (Macau)|Secretary for Administration and Justice]] Cheong Weng Chon (張永春) said that in accordance with the decision of the central government, endorsements for mainland Chinese visitors to Macau would be suspended.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nia.gov.cn/n741440/n741542/c1214127/content.html |script-title=zh:国家移民管理局暂停办理内地居民往来港澳地区旅游签注 |work=国家移民管理局 |language=zh-hk |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207074151/https://www.nia.gov.cn/n741440/n741542/c1214127/content.html |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} On 30 January, the Tertiary Education Bureau announced that the resumption of classes would be delayed further, and that a schedule for resuming classes would be released one week before classes were to resume.{{cite web |script-title=zh:本澳所有大專、非高等教育機構及私立補充教學輔助中心延遲開課至另行公佈 |url=https://www.dses.gov.mo/news/5179-2020-01-30 |accessdate=2020-01-31 |website=dses.gov.mo |date=2020-01-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207074315/https://www.dses.gov.mo/news/5179-2020-01-30 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} ===February 2020=== On 3 February, the government of Macau announced that starting at noon, all bus and taxi passengers were required to wear masks; otherwise the driver would have the right to refuse boarding.{{cite web |script-title=zh:乘客須佩戴口罩方可乘搭巴士 |url=https://www.dsat.gov.mo/dsat/news_detail.aspx?a_id=5FE497B2F8060898A9BBA44F10244BA6 |accessdate=2020-02-03 |date=2020-02-03 |language=zh-mo |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207074557/https://www.dsat.gov.mo/dsat/news_detail.aspx?a_id=5FE497B2F8060898A9BBA44F10244BA6 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |author1=澳門特別行政區政府交通事務局}}{{cite web |script-title=zh:乘客須佩戴口罩方可乘搭的士 |url=https://www.dsat.gov.mo/dsat/news_detail.aspx?a_id=074A4495F12B6EFE7C84E7B30431AF15 |accessdate=2020-02-03 |date=2020-02-03 |language=zh-mo |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207074655/https://www.dsat.gov.mo/dsat/news_detail.aspx?a_id=074A4495F12B6EFE7C84E7B30431AF15 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live |author1=澳門特別行政區政府交通事務局}} Starting at 13:00, all light rail passengers were required to wear a mask; otherwise the driver would have the right to refuse boarding.{{cite web |script-title=zh:NEWS.GOV.MO: －記者會快訊（防疫措施）－ |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BCzi7H3 |accessdate=2020-02-09 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-03 |work=news.gov.mo |publisher=新聞局 |language=zh-Hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200209075337/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BCzi7H3;jsessionid=EA578917F150E31435A7327F15BF9B8B.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-09 |url-status=live}} On 4 February 2020, all [[casino]]s in Macau were ordered to shut down for 15 days.{{Cite news |last=Stevenson |first=Alexandra |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/04/business/coronavirus-macau-gambling.html |title=Coronavirus Shuts Macau, the World's Gambling Capital |date=4 February 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=4 February 2020 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200204121004/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/04/business/coronavirus-macau-gambling.html |archive-date=4 February 2020 |url-status=live}}{{Cite news |last=Yang |first=Joyu Wang and Jing |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/deadly-coronavirus-forces-chinas-gambling-hub-to-shut-its-casinos-11580816447 |title=Coronavirus: Bad Luck Hits Macau Casinos With 15-Day Shutdown |date=4 February 2020 |work=The Wall Street Journal |access-date=4 February 2020 |issn=0099-9660 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200206113014/https://www.wsj.com/articles/deadly-coronavirus-forces-chinas-gambling-hub-to-shut-its-casinos-11580816447 |archive-date=6 February 2020 |url-status=live}} The following facilities were also required to close: cinemas, theatres, indoor amusement parks, arcades, internet cafes, pool halls, bowling alleys, steam baths, massage parlours, beauty salons, gyms, health clubs, bars, karaoke bars, nightclubs, discos, and dance clubs.{{cite web |script-title=zh:印務局 - 行政長官批示 |url=https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/05/despce_cn.asp |accessdate=2020-02-08 |author=行政長官 賀一誠 |date=2020-02-04 |work=bo.io.gov.mo |publisher=印務局 |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200204112701/https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/05/despce_cn.asp |archivedate=2020-02-04 |url-status=live}} On 7 February, the government of Macau announced that government workers were to stay home from the 8th to the 16th, except for emergency services.{{cite web |script-title=zh:NEWS.GOV.MO: 公務人員因防疫需要8至16號免除上班 |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BGROZbm |accessdate=2020-02-07 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-07 |work=news.gov.mo |publisher=新聞局 |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207115559/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BGROZbm;jsessionid=2ABAEBA2B2217366ECACFAFBEE4717F1.app01?0 |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} On 11 February, at the daily press conference, the government announced the third face mask safeguarding plan and provided masks for children for the first time, but due to limited quantities, each child was only permitted to buy five.{{cite web |script-title=zh:明天起有兒童口罩供應 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317960/ |accessdate=2020-02-11 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-11 |publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200211135351/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317960/ |archivedate=2020-02-11 |url-status=live}} The government also announced that testing would begin for groups at high risk of infection, and that the highest-risk group was tour bus drivers, of which 103 were to be tested that day.{{cite web |script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（擴大檢測範圍 安排旅遊巴司機檢測）－ |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317900/ |accessdate=2020-02-11 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-11 |publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200211135342/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317900/ |archivedate=2020-02-11 |url-status=live}} On 13 February the government announced economic relief measures, including: (1) reduction of taxes and fees to relieve the burden on businesses and residents; (2) assistance to small and medium enterprises and interest subsidies, to support the continued existence of enterprises; (3) measures to enhance people's livelihoods and support vulnerable families; (4) technical training, providing work, and protecting wages; (5) putting out electronic coupons to accelerate economic recovery.{{cite web |script-title=zh:紓解民困、共渡時艱 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318146/ |accessdate=2020-02-14 |author=經濟財政司司長辦公室 |date=2020-02-13 |publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200214125602/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318146/ |archivedate=2020-02-14 |url-status=live}} The government also announced that it would cooperate with a local research team in Macau to establish production lines in the mainland and safeguard the supply of face masks.{{cite web |script-title=zh:特區政府推多項經濟援助措施 抗疫工作初見成效 呼籲市民堅持防疫勿鬆懈 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318253/ |accessdate=2020-02-15 |author=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心 |date=2020-02-13 |publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200215114456/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318253/ |archivedate=2020-02-15 |url-status=live}} On 14 February, the government announced that, after balancing epidemic prevention with citizens' need for public services, starting 17 February, basic public services would be restored.{{cite web |script-title=zh:公共部門下周一起僅維持基本服務 – 澳門特別行政區政府入口網站 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318287/ |accessdate=2020-02-14 |author=行政法務司司長辦公室 |date=2020-02-14 |work=web.archive.org |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200214105827/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/318287/ |archivedate=2020-02-14}} On 17 February, the government announced that effective 20 February, casinos could reopen but other entertainment facilities such as cinemas and bars were to remain closed. The government also announced that migrant workers entering Macau who had been to mainland China in the past 14 days would need to undergo 14 days of medical observation at a designated location in [[Zhuhai]].{{cite web|script-title=zh:印務局 - 行政長官批示|url=https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/07/despce_cn.asp|accessdate=2020-02-17|author=|date=|format=|work=bo.io.gov.mo|publisher=|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200217090424/https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/07/despce_cn.asp|archivedate=2020-02-17|url-status=live|quote=}} At a press conference, the [[Secretariat for Economy and Finance (Macau)|Secretary for Economy and Finance]] Lei Wai Nong (李偉農) mentioned that when casinos reopened, they would have to follow government measures in order to protect employee and guest safety. If casinos were unable to prepare adequately for reopening, they could apply to delay reopening for up to 30 days.{{cite web|script-title=zh:李偉農：慎重處理娛樂場重開的後續工作|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319128/|accessdate=2020-02-17|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-17|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200217130429/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319128/|archivedate=2020-02-17|url-status=live}} On 18 February, due to the global face mask shortage, the government began providing masks with ties instead of ear straps.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（綁帶式或掛耳式口罩的防護效能相同）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319228/|accessdate=2020-02-18|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-18|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200218112834/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319228/|archivedate=2020-02-18|url-status=live}} On 19 February, the government announced that effective 20 February, passengers coming from COVID-19 hotspots would need to undergo medical checks upon entering Macau. Medical checks might also be conducted on Macau residents who made multiple trips back and forth to Zhuhai every day. It was also announced that some parks would reopen and government broadcasts would be adjusted.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（政府調整防疫措施）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319322/|accessdate=2020-02-19|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-19|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200219102214/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319322/|archivedate=2020-02-19|url-status=live}} All casinos reopened on 20 February 2020,{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/3051571/macau-casinos-reopen-after-coronavirus-shutdown-gamblers-keep-their|title=Gamblers hedge their bets as Macau casinos reopen to small crowds|date=2020-02-20|website=South China Morning Post|language=en|access-date=2020-02-21}} but visitor numbers remained low due to the pandemic, with hotels at less than 12% occupancy at the end of February.{{cite news |last1=Sullivan |first1=Lewis |title=Macau's gaming revenue fell 88 percent in February |url=https://www.casino-review.co/macau-gaming-revenue/ |accessdate=19 March 2020 |work=Casino Review}} Macau's casinos suffered a year-on-year revenue drop of 88% during February 2020, the worst ever recorded. Starting on 20 February, the government of Macau restricted entry from mainland China.{{cite news |title=Macau considering easing of entry restrictions from mainland China |url=https://www.asgam.com/index.php/2020/03/12/macau-considering-easing-of-entry-restrictions-from-mainland-china/ |accessdate=19 March 2020 |work=IAG |date=11 March 2020 |language=en}} On 21 February, the government announced that the following week, 24–28 February, the public sector would still provide basic services.{{cite web|script-title=zh:公共部門下周繼續維持基本服務|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319529/|accessdate=2020-02-21|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-21|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200221114529/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319529/|archivedate=2020-02-21|url-status=live}} The fourth face mask safeguarding plan would begin the following day, 22 February.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（第四輪保障口罩供應計劃明展開）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319573/|accessdate=2020-02-21|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-21|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200221115412/http://web.archive.org/screenshot/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319573/|archivedate=2020-02-21|url-status=live}} On 25 February, the Health Bureau announced that people entering Macau who had been to South Korea in the past 14 days would be required to undergo 14 days of medical observation.{{cite web|script-title=zh:NEWS.GOV.MO: 自明（26）日中午起曾到韓國的人士 需接受14天的隔離醫學觀察|url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BYhxp2c|accessdate=2020-02-25|date=2020-02-25|work=news.gov.mo|publisher=|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200225154838/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BYhxp2c;jsessionid=32474981D8F273844A20ADDCC779360E.app03?0|archivedate=2020-02-25|url-status=live}} The Maritime and Water Bureau announced that the opening hours of the [[Outer Harbour Ferry Terminal]] and [[Taipa Ferry Terminal]] would be changed to 07:00–20:00 until further notice.{{cite web|script-title=zh:NEWS.GOV.MO: 外港與氹仔客運碼頭調整開放時間|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320394/|accessdate=2020-02-25|author=海事及水務局|date=2020-02-25|work=news.gov.mo|publisher=|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200225154838/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320394/;jsessionid=32474981D8F273844A20ADDCC779360E.app03?0|archivedate=2020-02-25|url-status=live}} On 27 February,{{cite web|script-title=zh:印務局 - 行政長官批示|url=https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/08/despce_cn.asp#50|accessdate=2020-02-27|author=|date=2020-02-27|work=bo.io.gov.mo|publisher=|language=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227083042/https://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/2020/08/despce_cn.asp#50|archivedate=2020-02-27|url-status=live}} the other venues that had been closed on 5 February along with the casinos were permitted to reopen. However, the government of Macau recommended that they implement epidemic control measures; if an outbreak occurred in such a place, they would require site control measures in accordance with Article 19 of the Infectious Disease Prevention Law.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（將解除美容院等場所的關閉令）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320478/|accessdate=2020-02-27|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-27|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227104957/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320478/|archivedate=2020-02-27|url-status=live}} The government of Macau announced that effective 2 March, public services would return to normal.{{cite web|script-title=zh:公共部門下周一起恢復正常辦公|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320518/|accessdate=2020-02-27|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-27|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227110408/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320518/|archivedate=2020-02-27|url-status=live}} Private tutoring and continuing education institutions that meet health guidelines could also resume operations.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（補習社等於3月2日起分批分階段恢復運作）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320488/|accessdate=2020-02-27|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-27|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227110903/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320488/|archivedate=2020-02-27|url-status=live}} The Education Bureau announced that, subject to the conditions that Macau and [[Guangdong Province]] had no new confirmed cases for 14 consecutive days and Macau schools did not resume classes before Zhuhai and [[Zhongshan]], it would be possible to announce the resumption of classes at non-tertiary schools.{{cite web|script-title=zh:－記者會快訊（訂定非高等教育復課日的原則）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320473/|accessdate=2020-02-27|author=新聞局|date=2020-02-27|publisher=Government of Macau residents would be permitted to undergo medical observation at a home location deemed appropriate by authorities.{{cite web|script-title=zh:自今（29）日中午起曾到意大利或伊朗的入境人士須接受14天的隔離醫學觀察|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320881/|accessdate=2020-02-29|author=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心|date=2020-02-29|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200229112717/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/320881/|archivedate=2020-02-29|url-status=live}} ===March 2020=== On 2 March, many branches of the [[Macao Public Library]] reopened (with certain areas such as the multimedia rooms and children's reading areas remaining closed), and with the buildings receiving twice-daily "Cleaning and Disinfection Periods".{{Cite web|url=https://www.library.gov.mo/en/aboutus/notice/235|title=Library Opening Notice|last=|first=|date=2020-02-29|website=library.gov.mo|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-04-23}} On 8 March, it was announced that starting at noon the same day, people entering Macau who had been to Germany, France, Spain, or Japan in the past 14 days would need to undergo a health check. In addition, starting 10 March at noon, passengers coming from those locations would need to undergo 14 days of isolation and medical observation at a designated location. Macau residents would be permitted to undergo medical observation at an approved home location.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:本澳分別自今日及下周二中午起對曾到德國、法國、西班牙或日本的入境人士採取醫學檢查及14天隔離醫學觀察|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/322218/|accessdate=2020-03-08|author=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心|date=2020-03-08|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200305125732/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/322218/|archivedate=2020-03-08|url-status=live}} The Tertiary Education Bureau announced measures to help students from Macau studying abroad to purchase face masks.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:在外地就讀的澳門大學生可透過口罩保障計劃購買口罩|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/322289/|accessdate=2020-03-14|author=高等教育局|date=2020-03-08 |publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200314081930/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/322289/|archivedate=2020-03-14|url-status=live}} On 9 March, the Sports Bureau announced that sports facilities under its authority had gradually resumed opening starting 2 March, and that other facilities would be able to gradually resume opening starting 11 March. The Tourism Bureau announced that transportation from Hong Kong International Airport to a designated location would be arranged for Macau residents and students coming from the United States as well as European countries.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:明日零時起本澳對中國以外國家或地區入境人士實施醫學觀察措施 呼籲入境人士入境如實申報 居民如非必要勿外遊|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/323430/ |accessdate=2020-03-16 |author=新型冠狀病毒感染應變協調中心|date=2020-03-16 |publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200316154242/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/323430/ |archivedate=2020-03-16|url-status=live}} Effective 18 March, the government banned entry of all non-residents, with exceptions for mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.{{cite news |url=https://macaunews.mo/macau-prohibits-non-residents-from-entering-macau-with-the-exception-of-those-from-mainland-china-hong-kong-and-taiwan/|title=Macau Prohibits Non-Residents from Entering Macau with the exception of those from Mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan|website=Macau News |accessdate=19 March 2020}} On 18 March, the Tourism Bureau announced that from 19 March to 31 March, transportation from Hong Kong International Airport would take Macau residents and students coming from all countries to designated locations for medical observation.{{citation needed|date=April 2020}} On 19 March, the plan for resuming classes in stages was cancelled.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:非高等教育學校延期復課至另行再公布 |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/323922/|accessdate=2020-03-19|author=教育暨青年局|date=2020-03-19|format=|publisher=Government of Macao |language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200319114318/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/323922/ |archivedate=2020-03-19|url-status=live}} On 24 March, the chief executive announced that starting 25 March, connecting flights would no longer be permitted at [[Macau International Airport]]; any residents of Hong Kong, Taiwan, or mainland China who had been to other countries in the previous 14 days were prohibited from entering Macau; and Macau residents who had been to Hong Kong, Taiwan, or other countries in the past 14 days would be required to undergo 14 days of medical observation at a designated location.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:－行政長官記者會快訊（明起禁止入境前14天內曾到外國的非澳門居民入境）－|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/324556/|accessdate=2020-03-24|author=新聞局|date=2020-03-24|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200324031513/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/324556/|archivedate=24 March 2020|url-status=live}} On 25 March, the Health Bureau expanded restrictions on blood donations.{{Cite web|script-title=zh:捐血中心應對新型冠狀病毒肺炎的最新措施和呼籲捐血|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/325006/|accessdate=2020-03-25|author=|date=2020-03-25|publisher=Government of Macao|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200325131008/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/325006/|archivedate=2020-03-25|url-status=live}} ===April 2020=== On 4 April, the government of Macau followed the Chinese central government in holding a day of mourning throughout Macau. [[Chinese flag]]s and [[Macau flag]]s were to be flown at [[half mast]], and public entertainment and celebrations or festive events were to stop. Starting at 10 AM that day, Macau would observe a three-minute moment of silence.{{cite web |url=https://hd.stheadline.com/news/realtime/hk/1739427/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E6%B8%AF%E8%81%9E-%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E4%B8%8B%E5%85%A7%E5%9C%B0%E6%98%8E%E6%97%A5%E5%85%A8%E5%9C%8B%E5%93%80%E6%82%BC-%E6%BE%B3%E9%96%80%E5%B0%87%E4%B8%8B%E5%8D%8A%E6%97%97%E8%87%B4%E5%93%80 |script-title=zh:疫情下內地明日全國哀悼 澳門將下半旗致哀 |website=stheadline.com |language=zh-hk}} Effective 6 April, the government suspended bus links over the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]], only allowing dual licence (HK/Macau) and freight vehicles to use the bridge.{{cite web |title=Hong Kong-Macau delta bridge bus link suspended over COVID-19 threat (Update) |url=https://macaunews.mo/hong-kong-macau-delta-bridge-bus-link-suspended-over-covid-19-threat-update/ |website=Macao News |accessdate=5 April 2020 |date=5 April 2020}} On 8 April, the Secretary for Economy and Finance announced that 10 billion patacas would be put into an anti-epidemic assistance fund to help residents and businesses.{{cite news |title=澳门斥资百亿设抗疫基金：保就业 稳经济 顾民生 |url=https://money.163.com/20/0409/08/F9OPVULI00258105.html|access-date=2020-04-09|language=zh-CN}} On 20 April, the [[Education and Youth Affairs Bureau (Macau)|Education and Youth Affairs Bureau]] introduced a child mask plan to provide masks to children starting school.{{Cite web|title=中央登記幼兒口罩計劃－先登記、後領取、齊準備|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/327804/|accessdate=2020-04-20|author=教育暨青年局|date=2020-04-20|work=澳門特別行政區政府入口網站|publisher=|language=zh-hant|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200420141550/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/327804/|archivedate=2020-04-20}} On 25 April, the Education and Youth Affairs Bureau announced a testing plan for non-tertiary teachers and cross-border students, starting with testing 5,000 secondary school teachers.{{Cite web|title=-記者會快訊 (教職工和學生核酸檢測計劃內容)-|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/328555/|accessdate=2020-04-27|author=新聞局|date=2020-04-26|work=澳門特別行政區政府入口網站|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200427032409/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/328555/|archivedate=2020-04-27|url-status=live}} On 28 April, the Marine and Water Bureau announced that starting April 29 at midnight (00:00), fishers returning to Macau would need to quarantine for 14 days on the fishing boat or at a hotel. Fishers who had already returned to Macau would be tested.{{Cite web|title=電台新聞>明起返澳漁民需醫學觀察隔離14天(2020.04.28 13:10)|url=https://www.tdm.com.mo/c_news/radio_news.php?id=466590|accessdate=2020-05-01|work=www.tdm.com.mo}} ===May 2020=== On 1 May, the health bureau introduced the Macau health code, which was to start being used on May 3 at 9:00. The health code is an upgraded version of a personal health declaration, which would replace the health declarations being used at border crossings. For the time being, it would only apply to entering Macau and entering local places.{{Cite web|title=電台新聞>澳門健康碼後日起投入使用 以顏色識別進入場所(2020.05.01 17:35)|url=https://www.tdm.com.mo/c_news/radio_news.php?id=467049|accessdate=2020-05-01|work=www.tdm.com.mo|language=zh-hant}} On 2 May, it was agreed to resume regular hours of operation at [[Portas do Cerco]] and the [[Hong Kong–Zhuhai–Macau Bridge]].{{Cite web|title=關閘及港珠澳大橋口岸由5月3日起恢復正常通關時間|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/329218/|accessdate=2020-05-02|author=中華人民共和國澳門特別行政區海關（SA）|date=2020-05-02|work=澳門特別行政區政府入口網站|publisher=|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=|archivedate=|url-status=live}} ==Controversies== ===Free medical treatment for patients from mainland China=== At a press conference, [[Ho Iat Seng]] welcomed mainland Chinese people to make use of Macau's free medical service. This created controversy online, with users worrying that people from the mainland would come to Macau and spread the virus. Afterwards, Secretary for Administration and Justice Cheong Weng Chon (張永春) said that any patients from outside Macau who had COVID-19 would need to pay their own medical bills; they would be able to apply for a fee waiver, and the government would make a decision based on their financial situation and effects on the public.{{Cite news |url=http://www.macaodaily.com/html/2020-02/07/content_1414291.htm |title=衛局：不獲批追收鄂婦治療費 |date=2020-02-07 |work=澳門日報 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207134822/http://www.macaodaily.com/html/2020-02/07/content_1414291.htm |archivedate=2020-02-07 |url-status=live}} The first recovered patient{{Cite web|title=澳門首例確診病人今日康復出院 無新增新型冠狀病毒肺炎確診病例|url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317349/|accessdate=2020-03-03|author=衞生局|date=2020-03-03|work=澳門特別行政區政府入口網站|publisher=|language=zh-hant|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200303141814/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/317349/|archivedate=2020-03-03|url-status=live}} was a businesswoman from Wuhan. The Health Bureau stated that medical fees for people from outside Macau were double the fees for locals. The patient had applied to waive 34,000 [[patacas]] in medical fees. Internet users investigated and said that in the photos of her leaving the hospital, a handbag could be seen worth 20,000 patacas, and that the hotel she stayed at was more than 1000 patacas a night, concluding that she could afford the medical fees. This created a significant controversy. The bureau said they would make a determination in accordance with the law.{{Cite web |title=NEWS.GOV.MO: —記者會快訊（有關珠海新確診病例在澳期間的情況）— |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BGe1xc2 |accessdate=2020-02-07 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-07 |work=news.gov.mo |publisher=新聞局 |language=zh-hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207114546/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BGe1xc2?78 |archivedate=2020-02-07}} While in the hospital, the first confirmed patient requested [[hot dry noodles]], a dish from Wuhan, so the hospital specially arranged a Hubei chef. When leaving the hospital there were more expenses, causing locals to envy the patient's "five-star service". This caused controversy on the internet in both Macau and Hong Kong. The director of [[Conde S. Januário Hospital]] Lei Wai Seng (李偉成) said that the hospital's goal is not to provide special meals to patients, but rather that nutrition is important for a patient's recovery; if the patient's nutrition is inadequate, it's bad for their recovery. He emphasised that all patients are treated equally with respect to meals, and that the cost of meals is included in the hospital bill.{{Cite news |url=https://aamacau.com/2020/02/07/%E5%B1%B1%E9%A0%82%E3%80%8C%E6%98%9F%E7%B4%9A%E6%9C%8D%E5%8B%99%E3%80%8D%E6%83%B9%E5%B8%82%E6%B0%91%E7%9C%BC%E7%B4%85-%E6%9D%8E%E5%81%89%E6%88%90%EF%B8%B0%E4%BB%BB%E4%BD%95%E7%97%85%E4%BA%BA%E8%86%B3/ |title=山頂「星級服務」惹市民眼紅 李偉成︰任何病人膳食一視同仁 |date=2020-02-07 |work=aamacau |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200207132930/https://aamacau.com/2020/02/07/%E5%B1%B1%E9%A0%82%E3%80%8C%E6%98%9F%E7%B4%9A%E6%9C%8D%E5%8B%99%E3%80%8D%E6%83%B9%E5%B8%82%E6%B0%91%E7%9C%BC%E7%B4%85-%E6%9D%8E%E5%81%89%E6%88%90%EF%B8%B0%E4%BB%BB%E4%BD%95%E7%97%85%E4%BA%BA%E8%86%B3/ |archivedate=2020-02-07|url-status=live}} ===Closing the border=== When Guangdong became the province with the second-most cases in China, Macau still had tens of thousands of people going to and from Zhuhai every day. Many people asked for the border to be closed, but the government repeatedly said that a complete closure was not possible. Ho Iat Seng said, "If we closed all the ports of entry, who would remove the trash? Who would handle security? How would we get fresh produce? These are the issues we're thinking about."{{Cite web |title=當斷不斷 反受其亂 防控疫戰 封關制勝 |url=https://www.facebook.com/sonpou/posts/2487100484889511 |date=2020-02-07 |work=訊報 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200214044424/https://www.facebook.com/sonpou/posts/2487100484889511 |archivedate=2020-02-14 |url-status=live}}{{Cite web|title=賀一誠：澳門不會封關 目前經濟損失仍可承擔|url=http://www.aastocks.com/tc/stocks/news/aafn-con/NOW.990806/popular-news|accessdate=2020-02-14|author=|date=|format=|work=AASTOCKS.COM|publisher=|language=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200214044437/http://www.aastocks.com/tc/stocks/news/aafn-con/NOW.990806/popular-news|archivedate=2020-02-14|url-status=live}} ===Closing parks=== In February 2020, in order to prevent spread of the virus, the government announced that all country parks and municipal parks would be closed, to avoid crowds and reduce the risk of infection. Some residents were unhappy with this, feeling that the risk of transmission in the suburbs was very low, and that staying at home for a long time without going outside to exercise would increase the risk of other diseases.{{Cite web |title=【來論】希望抗疫期間，留市民一片郊野 |url=https://aamacau.com/2020/02/08/%E3%80%90%E4%BE%86%E8%AB%96%E3%80%91%E5%B8%8C%E6%9C%9B%E6%8A%97%E7%96%AB%E6%9C%9F%E9%96%93%EF%BC%8C%E7%95%99%E5%B8%82%E6%B0%91%E4%B8%80%E7%89%87%E9%83%8A%E9%87%8E/?fbclid=IwAR185INjm4R66IVO-BXByPA6SvnOBlRepdER4camVJj_a2UeyL4Ka9TqPak |accessdate=2020-02-08 |date=2020-02-08 |language=zh-Hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200208081302/https://aamacau.com/2020/02/08/%E3%80%90%E4%BE%86%E8%AB%96%E3%80%91%E5%B8%8C%E6%9C%9B%E6%8A%97%E7%96%AB%E6%9C%9F%E9%96%93%EF%BC%8C%E7%95%99%E5%B8%82%E6%B0%91%E4%B8%80%E7%89%87%E9%83%8A%E9%87%8E/?fbclid=IwAR185INjm4R66IVO-BXByPA6SvnOBlRepdER4camVJj_a2UeyL4Ka9TqPak |archivedate=2020-02-08 |url-status=live}} The Center for Disease Control and Prevention said that railings and similar could become a mode of transmission, that it's difficult to wear a mask when exercising, and that it's easy to end up starting a conversation if you run into a friend; these could all increase the risk of transmitting the virus. The government decided to close public recreation facilities in order to avoid community transmission.{{Cite web |title=NEWS.GOV.MO: —記者會快訊（關閉公共休憩設施）— |url=https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BHtzW6u |accessdate=2020-02-08 |author=新聞局 |date=2020-02-08 |publisher=澳門特別行政區政府新聞局 |language=zh-Hant |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200208114841/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20BHtzW6u;jsessionid=AF76980FE619421B35986BA900394923.app02?0 |archivedate=2020-02-08}} On 17 February, the government announced that casinos would reopen starting 20 February, but at the same time warned that the epidemic remained serious and advised residents to stay home and avoid going out. In addition, public parks and other public facilities would remain closed. In response, some residents questioned whether these measures and recommendations were contradictory, saying sarcastically that the government doesn't let people go to the park to exercise but does let them go to the casino to gamble.{{Cite web |url=https://aamacau.com/2020/02/22/%e9%98%b2%e7%96%ab%e4%b8%8d%e8%83%bd%e3%80%8c%e8%99%8e%e9%a0%ad%e8%9b%87%e5%b0%be%e3%80%8d-%e8%98%87%e5%98%89%e8%b1%aa%ef%bc%9a%e7%84%a1%e6%b3%95%e6%8e%a5%e5%8f%97%e6%94%bf%e5%ba%9c%e3%80%8c%e5%8d%8a/ |date=2020-02-22 |website=論盡媒體 AllAboutMacau Media |language=zh-hant |script-title=zh:防疫不能「虎頭蛇尾」 蘇嘉豪：無法接受政府「半套果斷」 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200225090029/https://aamacau.com/2020/02/22/%e9%98%b2%e7%96%ab%e4%b8%8d%e8%83%bd%e3%80%8c%e8%99%8e%e9%a0%ad%e8%9b%87%e5%b0%be%e3%80%8d-%e8%98%87%e5%98%89%e8%b1%aa%ef%bc%9a%e7%84%a1%e6%b3%95%e6%8e%a5%e5%8f%97%e6%94%bf%e5%ba%9c%e3%80%8c%e5%8d%8a/ |archive-date=2020-02-25 |access-date=2020-02-25}} The government responded that after an evaluation, the decision to reopen casinos was made to balance the needs of epidemic prevention and local workers' employment. When the casinos reopened, epidemic prevention measures would be required to protect the health of employees and guests.{{Cite web |url=https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319285/ |date=2020-02-18 |language=zh-hant |script-title=zh:娛樂場重開：重視風險、穩定就業 |trans-title=Reopening of casinos: focus on risks, stabilize employment |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200225090726/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hant/news/319285/ |archive-date=2020-02-25 |access-date=2020-02-25 |script-work=zh:博彩監察協調局 |trans-work=Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau}} In addition, the government announced on 19 February that some parks would reopen. ==References== {{reflist}} {{COVID-19 pandemic}} {{Portal bar|COVID-19|Medicine|Viruses}} [[Category:COVID-19 pandemic by dependent territory|Macau]] [[Category:COVID-19 pandemic in China by city|Macau]] [[Category:Disease outbreaks in Macau]] [[Category:2020 in Macau]] [[Category:COVID-19 pandemic in Asia|Macau]]
